1   package org.infinispan.configuration.cache;
2   
3   import static org.infinispan.configuration.cache.SingleFileStoreConfiguration.FRAGMENTATION_FACTOR;
4   import static org.infinispan.configuration.cache.SingleFileStoreConfiguration.LOCATION;
5   import static org.infinispan.configuration.cache.SingleFileStoreConfiguration.MAX_ENTRIES;
6   
7   import org.infinispan.commons.configuration.Builder;
8   /**
9    * Single file cache store configuration builder.
10   *
11   * @author Galder Zamarre√±o
12   * @since 6.0
13   */
14  public class SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder
15        extends AbstractStoreConfigurationBuilder<SingleFileStoreConfiguration, SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder> {
16  
17  
18     public SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder(PersistenceConfigurationBuilder builder) {
19        super(builder, SingleFileStoreConfiguration.attributeDefinitionSet());
20     }
21  
22     @Override
23     public SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder self() {
24        return this;
25     }
26  
27     /**
28      * Sets a location on disk where the store can write.
29      */
30     public SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder location(String location) {
31        attributes.attribute(LOCATION).set(location);
32        return this;
33     }
34  
35     /**
36      * In order to speed up lookups, the single file cache store keeps an index
37      * of keys and their corresponding position in the file. To avoid this
38      * index resulting in memory consumption problems, this cache store can
39      * bounded by a maximum number of entries that it stores. If this limit is
40      * exceeded, entries are removed permanently using the LRU algorithm both
41      * from the in-memory index and the underlying file based cache store.
42      *
43      * So, setting a maximum limit only makes sense when Infinispan is used as
44      * a cache, whose contents can be recomputed or they can be retrieved from
45      * the authoritative data store.
46      *
47      * If this maximum limit is set when the Infinispan is used as an
48      * authoritative data store, it could lead to data loss, and hence it's
49      * not recommended for this use case.
50      */
51     public SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder maxEntries(int maxEntries) {
52        attributes.attribute(MAX_ENTRIES).set(maxEntries);
53        return this;
54     }
55  
56     /**
57      * The store tries to fit in a new entry into an existing entry from a free entry pool (if one is available)
58      * However, this existing free entry may be quite bigger than what is required to contain the new entry
59      * It may then make sense to split the free entry into two parts:
60      * 1. That is required to contain the new entry requested
61      * 2. the remaining part to be returned to the pool of free entries.
62      * The fragmentationFactor decides when to split the free entry.
63      * So, if this value is set as 0.75, then the free entry will be split if the new entry is equal to or less than 0.75 times the size of free entry
64      */
65     public SingleFileStoreConfigurationBuilder fragmentationFactor(float fragmentationFactor) {
66        attributes.attribute(FRAGMENTATION_FACTOR).set(fragmentationFactor);
67        return this;
68     }
69  
70     @Override
71     public SingleFileStoreConfiguration create() {
72        return new SingleFileStoreConfiguration(attributes.protect(), async.create(), singletonStore.create());
73     }
74  
75     @Override
76     public Builder<?> read(SingleFileStoreConfiguration template) {
77        super.read(template);
78        return this;
79     }
80  
81  }
